author: Emma McKee
title: Paul McCartney Said The Beatles Could Be ‘Very Chauvinist’: ‘Women at That Time Got Sidelined’
text:
Paul McCartney Said The Beatles Could Be ‘Very Chauvinist’: ‘Women at That Time Got Sidelined’
In the early years of
The Beatles, Paul McCartney said the band was incredibly tight-knit. They lived, toured, and wrote music together. While each of them had serious long-term relationships in the early years of the band, McCartney said their band relationships were more important to them. He admitted that this made them chauvinistic.
Paul McCartney said The Beatles were so tight-knit they could be ‘chauvinist’
In 1963, McCartney met Jane Asher, an actor. The couple dated for five years and McCartney lived with her at her parents’ home for a portion of this time. While he said it was a “good relationship,” she was not his primary focus. His bandmates were.
“To tell the truth, the women at that time got sidelined,” he said in The Beatles Anthology. “Now it would be seen as very chauvinist of us. Then it was like: ‘We are four miners who go down the pit. You don’t need women down the pit, do you? We won’t have women down the pit.’”
McCartney admitted that the band dynamic could not have been easy on their romantic partners.
“A lot of what we, The Beatles, did was very much in an enclosed scene,” he said. “Other people found it difficult — even John’s wife, Cynthia, found it very difficult — to penetrate the screen that we had around us. As a kind of safety barrier we had a lot of ‘in’ jokes, little signs, references to music; we had a common bond in that and it was very difficult for any ‘outsider’ to penetrate. That possibly wasn’t good for relationships back then.”
John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison, and Ringo Starr relied on each other in The Beatles
Ringo Starr agreed with McCartney’s assessment of The Beatles. He admitted that they grew apart as years passed. Still, he believed that they were
closer than most bands.
“I don’t know of any other band who got that close,” Starr told Club Sandwich in 1997 (via
The Paul McCartney Project). “And we got that close because we loved each other and the pressure that only the Beatles had. No other band has had that much pressure. So all of those factors come into play when we meet each other. We know what went on. Nobody else knows. Everybody thinks they know, and they have ideas, and they write books about it, but actually only the Beatles know how heavy that was.”
John Lennon said it was embarrassing to have a wife and child
To further prove McCartney’s point, John Lennon said he found it
embarrassing to be married with a child. He wanted his first wife, Cynthia, to keep their relationship quiet and he saw her very little once the band began touring.
“I did feel embarrassed, walking around married,” he said, per the book John Lennon: The Life by Philip Norman. “It felt like walking round with odd socks on or your flies open.”
He, like McCartney, preferred the company of his bandmates at the time.

author: Canadian Press
title: Abby Stonehouse leads Canada past Czechia at world women's under-18 hockey event
text:
ZUG, Switzerland — Abby Stonehouse scored two short-handed goals and added three assists to lead Canada past Czechia 8-1 on Sunday at the world under-18 women's hockey championship.
Stonehouse score twice in the second period for Canada (2-0), which opened the tournament Saturday with an 11-0 victory over Germany. Morgan Jackson and Caitlin Kraemer (two apiece), Emma Venusio and Mackenzie Alexander had the other goals.
Aneta Paroubkova replied for Czechia (0-2).
Kraemer had two goals Saturday to become Canada's national women's under-18 all-time leading goal scorer with 17.
Kraemer opened the scoring with a short-handed goal at 12:28 of the first. But Canada broke the game open in the second, outscoring Czechia 4-1 in the period.
Stonehouse put Canada ahead 2-0 at 1:43 before scoring her second of the period at 8:20. Venusio made it 4-0 with the man advantage at 16:15 before Paroubkova scored at 17:38.
But Jackson countered at 19:27 to give the Canadians a four-goal advantage.
Jackson added her second of the game at 7:47 of the third. Kraemer and Alexander scored at 10:39 and 15:55, respectively, to round out the scoring.
This report by The Canadian Press was first published Jan. 7, 2024.
The Canadian Press

author: NBC2 News
title: Trio arrested for home invasion robbery coordinated through escort service website
text: Trio arrested for home invasion robbery coordinated through escort service website Three people were arrested after a scheme through an escort service website led to a man being tied up in a Port Charlotte home invasion robbery. According to the Charlotte County Sheriff's Office, the man made arrangements online with a 27-year-old Lee County woman identified as Amber Nicole Brown. The two met on August 2. Approximately 15 minutes after Brown arrived, two men knocked on the victim's front door. The men, later identified as Christopher Clark and Pete Bertolotti, said they lost their dog but then forced their way into the home. The duo had a hammer and crowbar and pushed the homeowner to the ground. Clark and Bertolotti then moved the man to the bedroom where they duct-taped his hands and feet, CCSO said. They commanded the victim to tell them where the money he promised Brown was. According to the report, they also forced him to unlock his phone and transferred the payment to Brown. After leaving the victim tied up, they shut the door and rummaged through his phone before leaving. The man was able to chew through the duct tape around his hands and hop to the kitchen. He was able to cut his feet free with scissors but noticed several sets of keys to his vehicles were missing. A vehicle was also missing from his driveway, along with his cellphone, and he ran to his neighbor's home to call 911. Not long after, a Lee County K9 deputy noticed a vehicle speeding down McGregor Boulevard. They discovered it was the stolen vehicle that belonged to the victim. According to the report, the driver ignored the deputy's attempts to stop them and began cutting through parking lots. The driver then hit a curb, causing a tire to go flat. The suspects then ran away. The Lee County deputy and his K9 were able to track down Brown, Clark and Bertolotti to an apartment complex where they were arrested. Clark and Bertolotti are being held in Lee County Jail on unrelated charges. However, CCSO said they will also face charges for this incident in Charlotte County. Brown is being held in Charlotte County Jail on a $100,000 bond and facing the following charges: - Home invasion robbery with a weapon - False imprisonment of a person against their will - Battery on a person 65 years or older DOWNLOAD the free [NBC2 News app](https://www.flowcode.com/page/nbc2-news-app) for the latest alerts on this story

author: esportenewsmundo
title: Bahia acerta a contratação de promessa do Flamengo
text:
Bahia acerta a contratação de promessa do Flamengo
O lateral-esquerdo de 18 anos foi campeão da Libertadores Sub-20 pelo Flamengo e assinou contrato com o Tricolor até o final de 2027.
O Bahia acertou a contratação do lateral-direito Lucyan, campeão da Libertadores e do Mundial Sub-20 pelo Flamengo na temporada passada. O jogador de 18 anos assinou contrato com o Tricolor até o final de 2027.
A multa rescisória do lateral será de 100 milhões de euros (cerca de R$618 milhões) para transferências ao exterior.
Lucyan é visto como mais um reforço de peso para as categorias de base do Bahia. Em 2025, o Tricolor contratou o atacante David Martins, do América Mineiro, por R$12 milhões, e o lateral-esquerdo Zé Guilherme, do Grêmio.
O novo reforço Tricolor foi titular do Flamengo na reta final da conquista da Libertadores de 2024, disputando a final diante do Boca Juniors. No Mundial daquele ano, Lucyan foi reserva do time que venceu o Olympiacos e era treinado por Filipe Luís.

author: Erica Collura
title: Big warm up for the weekend
text: Much warmer air is arriving this weekend, with temperatures about 10 degrees above average. High clouds will venture in later today, filtering out some sun, with temperatures topping out at 79 degrees. Tonight, skies remain mostly clear, with lows staying mild. We'll stay around 60 into Sunday morning. A few more clouds move in associated with a cold front nearing the area. This may trigger a couple of showers, but overall Sunday looks dry. Temperatures will get back into the upper 70s with breezy conditions. Winds will be out of the southwest around 15 mph. Gusts up to 30 mph are possible. After the front passes, much cooler air will be ushered in for Monday. Temperatures will start off in the 40s and only get to the low 62s. It gets even cooler Tuesday, with highs in the 50s. Some areas of frost will be possible Tuesday through Thursday morning.
